review:
Part of the LoveKami series, it is not a sequel to LoveKami Divinity Stage, but it shares many similarities in storyline, and artistic elements.

ARTWORK:
Characters are well drawn and there is a fair bit of CGs, including chibi ones. 

The game uses the Emote M2 engine to animate characters' bodies and expressions - with very good results.

There is a fair amount of skimpy clothing, exposed skin, and lewd scenes, and it it goes without saying that fan service is the focus of this visual novel, something it does very well.

STORY:
Plot is your generic harem story though with a failed goddess and her mythical companion that end up in Earth - together with humans - and end up enamored with a human man. Unlike the first installment, there is also a story line with a human partner as well.

Story is mostly linear with a single choice that branches off the different heroines' routes.

Story development is better than it was in the first installment, and the different story branches have a little more variety, though endings are very predictable.

SOUND:
Music is decent though not particularly memorable, and fits the over the top atmosphere yet generic nature of the story. 

The novel has full voice acting in Japanese, which is of good quality.

SUMMARY: 
Those that want a fan service story with artwork and plot to match, and not care much about story development, will be interested. 8/10.

review:
There are 3 LoveKami games. Each one has it's own characters and are NOT linked character wise (Your character and The other Characters are different for each game). The 3 games together are about $6 for ALL 3 or about $2.50 for each individual game (when on sale)... You ONLY get ONE choice to make per game.

PROS:

Useless Goddess - In my opinion "Useless Goddess" had the best story, characters, and was the most interesting to me as well. "Divinity Stage" has a kind of boring story and "Harem" is way too... Well too Ecchi and Haremy for me... I really only liked "Useless Goddess" so I recommend that one!

Ecchi - This game has a lot of is. IF that is what you came for you will get it here. the "Harem" game has the most, while this game does have it but not as much.

Akane - She is my FAVORITE character... I really enjoyed her story and what happenswith our character and her. She is definitely my choice!

CONS:

Story - At least for the other two games I thought the story was kinda boring for the first one(Divinity), while being more innocent... and the last game (Harem) didn't really have a great story either and was just about haremy stuff... This game "Useless Goddess" has a pretty interesting story in my opinion and the characters are a bit more unique in my opinion.

Only One Choice - Each game ONLY has one choice. That choice is what character to choose as your LOVE for the game [Spoiler] CHOOSE AKANE!!! She is the BEST ONE [/Spoiler]

CONCLUSION:

IF you like the Ecchi stuff LoveKami might be a game for you. IF you do NOT like so much Ecchi then this game might provide a bit too much (IT is not a Hentai game... I don't have any hentai games but this series has the most Ecchi stuff I have ever seen and it's pretty distracting).

For this game " Useless Goddess" if you are okay with ecchi... The story is better then the other two in my opinion so I would recommend this version if you chose ONE game... One sale it is about $2.50 (You can get all three games for like $6 when on sale but I would just get this ONE GAME. I own all three but I really just liked this one).

These classes are igneous rocks, which have solidified from molten material called magma; sedimentary rocks, those consisting of fragments derived from preexisting rocks or of materials precipitated from solutions; and metamorphic rocks, which have been derived from either igneous or sedimentary rocks under conditions that caused changes in mineralogical composition, texture, and internal structure. author: {'steamid': '76561197996503472', 'num_games_owned': 966, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1621398159}
review:
An [i]aggressively[/i] mediocre kinetic novel (it's not a visual novel, a visual novel is a game where you have agency and the ability to control what your protagonist does and how the story goes, not just one where you make a single choice of which one of three entirely-linear stories you read at a time), LoveKami -Useless Goddess- is dull, cliche, and really very glurgy. The plot never really goes anywhere, the conclusions to each story route are incredibly weak, and the initial story thread (convincing a slacker goddess to become a pop idol to make something of herself) NEVER gets resolved in any of the routes- that's right, Akane NEVER becomes a pop idol, even in her own story. The characters are one-note, not terribly engaging, and Akane in particular, the titular "Useless Goddess" herself, is actually rather irritating.

It's hard to say this without sounding like the kind of mouth-breathing neckbeard who humps his anime love pillow every night, but the story genuinely suffers badly from NOT being a H-game. There IS an adults-only version of the game, but this isn't it, there's no patch for it, and nobody cares enough to make a mod for it. I've never had much regard for ecchi, and this game is a prime example of why- in the last third of each route you're in a serious romantic relationship with one of the girls, and the fact that things never actually do escalate physically is honestly implausible. It's not like the game is SFW anyway- being an ecchi game means all three girls (Akane, Inori and Maika) have bosoms like barrage balloons, cleavages you could lose a chihuahua in, and dress like streetwalkers. Akane's top is so skimpy you can literally see her areolas peeping over the edges, Inori's is so low-cut it would make Lulu from FFX blush, and Maika's low-cut sweater has her lace-trimmed bra visibly showing over it, and there are scenes in the game where Akane bukkakes ice-cream onto her boobs and invites you to lick it off, Inori crawls through a hole too small for her and almost displays her entire package at you when her clothes get stuck, and Maika responds to you accidentally nicking your finger with a knife by performing fellatio on it. So the game is as lewd as hell, but lacks any actual SEX that would give the romantic relationships some real weight. It's like a schoolboy who steals his father's cigarettes and puts one in his mouth to try and convince his classmates he's "cool", but is too afraid to actually light it (not that I'm in any way endorsing underage smoking, mind, or smoking at ANY age, but you get what I mean, right?).

Technically the game is nothing special. The much-vaunted E-Mote system just turns the girls into paper dolls that sway back and forth like trees in the breeze, occasionally blinking, while their mouths switch between a closed sprite and an open sprite that shrinks and stretches to simulate speaking. The girls have 1 pose, 2 outfits and a handful of facial expressions each, and you can probably count the total number of backgrounds on your fingers (with variants for different times of day and lighting). Nekopara this is not.

Not the worst kinetic novel masquerading as a visual novel I've ever wasted time on (that's still Sakura Spirit), LoveKami -Useless Goddess- still isn't very interesting or worth your time. I only picked it up because the publisher bundle was on sale, and it was still quite a chore to get through. Not worth your time, unless you just want some giant boobs and don't care that you never actually get to see them bare.

review: LoveKami -Useless Goddess- is a romantic visual novel centered around Akane, a 'useless' goddess who causes more trouble than a goddess should. She has to acclimate to human society accompanied by the shy, beloved fellow goddess Inori and Maika, your landlord and childhood friend. You all must work to help the rebellious Akane get her act together before it's too late. With their own distinct personalities, any of the three girls can be chosen as your love interest and each route is charming and fun in its own way. There are a couple hilarious and lewd scenes that appear throughout the course of the story. The character art was expressive with beautiful scenery, great voice acting and a bubbly soundtrack. Coming in at just shy of 4 hours with all achievements, I find faster-paced visual novels like LoveKami -Useless Goddess- really enjoyable. I'd recommend it to any fans of the genre.

[i] "Her eyes are up there, anon." [/i]

Where do I start.. it gives a very different take on the [i] LoveKami [/i] series, instead of Divine Idols in Divinity Stage [strike] though it is mentioned but you don't see any of it here [/strike].

It gives you three routes same as the previous game, but all three of them follow a common route but it gives a different scenario and ending depending on the route you picked. I noticed that how the three routes somehow follow a similar pattern of events and/or conflicts from each other, like they follow a same path but its completely different from each other.

You don't need to do any trial and error in choosing the right choices on the route you want to go to, there's only one part in which character you'll choose to be with and it will start on that character's route.

As said before it is very different from Divinity Stage but it keeps the idea of Goddesses living together with humans, this time no divine idols, it's a useless goddess.  It gives a romance, slice of life, and a rather lewd stuff.

I highly recommend that you don't play this in a public place, some CGs of this visual novel is questionable that it almost felt like this game is a barely censored version. The characters in this game are different from Divinity Stage, they all show different personalities, emotions, and goals. They have their own goals, backstory, and conflict, it is worth reading them all.

I felt weird when I was in the credits movie, it took me off-guard on the song used in the credits, it made feel like [i] "Did I get the bad ending?" [/i] after finishing a route yet it's not bad, it somehow fits. Overall, it seems short since my whole gameplay took me 9 hours, but it was worth reading all of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198285217510', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1574792050}
review:
LoveKami -Useless Goddess- takes place in the same universe as previous title (Divinity Stage) with 3 new characters - two are goddesses and one is a tsundere childhood friend. 

The story this time is much better compared to the previous game with few plot twists in each route. I felt that it was a bit longer and each route had its own plot instead of one common plot which is viewed from different perspectives as in Divinity Stage.

The main route which is Akane route is probably the best one and also the most consistent with the main plot line. Akane's character is also very adorable and likeable and I really enjoyed this route so if you plan to play only through one route, I would recommend this one.

The second best was Maika route, her character is your typical tsundere archetype but not as annoying as many other tsunderes. And she had the best character development in my opinion. Also very enjoyable route.

The last route is Inori route which I personally didn't enjoy at all, mostly because of the plot which was really boring and Inori's character is also one of those I don't really like that much. The whole route was kinda snorefest and I was just hoping it would end.

Visuals are still as good as ever with very detailed background and character design (the boobs are still huge and it's really ridiculous at times). The colour pallete is also nice.

The most disappointing part for me was the soundtrack which was very short, only 10 tracks and around 20 minutes of duration which is much shorter compared to Divinity Stage soundtrack. At least voice acting was great, especially Akane's seiyuu did a great work. Our male MC is not voice acted again though.

Certainly nice little VN with around 8 hours of playtime. If you like romance then there is a chance you might enjoy this VN. But I would recommend to wait for a sale because I don't think it is worth its full price tag.

review:
I only bought it cause it was on sale.  Not worth the 14 dollars if it wasn't.  Animations are mediocre.  Instead of drawing another image of a situation they simply explain it in the dialog with a blank picture of an empty room most of the time.  Not much effort was put into this VN.  You can always tell how good a VN's story is based on how much dialog choices there are. Well..THIS one is close to not having  any choices at all. Id recommend this if it was a free to play. Or if it was  4 dollars or less all the time.
Another thing to add is the frequent spelling errors.  Two of which I remember. They spelled restaurant and maybe wrong in some of the conversations.  Just to name a few.

Would not recommend. Unless you want to play 14 dollars to stare at the same giant boobs for 2 hours. Which you can do for free on any image site...

author: {'steamid': '76561197972458635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1687726725}
review:
It's MoeNovel; it's good; NEXT!  

Okay, although the above is true, by the numbers: LoveKami: Useless Goddess is the second installment of the LoveKami series which is set in a world where Japanese goddesses came down from... well, wherever Japanese goddesses come down from, and began to live amongst the common folk usually in the form of cute young ladies.  Some are Jimigami; beatific, selfless helpers,  while a few are Aragami; mischievous, and a bit self centered pains in the tochis, but decent enough down deep: think Thor and Loki without all the cool MCU fight scenes.  

This time around, our protag-kun Sho, meets an Aragami named Akane (the Useless Goddess) who is on the run from being rehabilitated by a Jimigami named Inori who has been tasked with cleaning up Akane's act, and getting Akane's Jinriki (divine power) under control.  Sho takes the itinerant Akane back to the apartments where he lives under the watchful eye of his childhood friend Maika, and the hijinks begin.  I don't want to spoil it beyond that.  

LoveKami: Useless Goddess has the great artwork, CG scenes, and animation that we have come to expect from MoeNovel, and the soundtrack and voice work is top notch as always.  The UI is standard and intuitive enough to be easily useful to newbies and veterans of visual novels.  MoeNovel pretty much sets the standard.

The story is lighthearted, as you work through any of the three available routes.  One is pretty obviously the main route, and flows pretty well with no real hiccups, but the other two routes seemed a little strained to me; almost as if they were more tacked on to fill out the usual need for multiple routes which make it a romance/dating sim, and not just a kinetic visual novel.  There is no "Bad" ending here, although the addition of one might have been interesting. In any case, LoveKami: Useless Goddess does have a good story, and I would give it a 3.5 out of 5.

review:
It's not awful. Pretty much all romance scenes were heartwarming and adorable. Voice acting is pretty good too.
If you are just looking for a consequence-free love story, feel free to pick this up.

Now that said I find all of the characters in this VN tiresome and generic in a bad way. Their actions and motivations are pointlessly inconsistent across the different routes. That felt especially bothersome after finishing [spoiler]Maika[/spoiler] route first, as the already established backstory of [spoiler]the promise and her feelings[/spoiler] were completely shrugged off! I felt like I was [spoiler]cheating on her[/spoiler] and it didn't show in the characters the slightest.

Okay I have seen this kinda behavior to be common in these all-happy-endings VNs but I really hoped there would be more effort put into consistency. This is after all supposed to be a story with three different endings depending on my actions as opposed to three totally different stories with a common prologue.

Speaking of which, let's talk about [spoiler]Inori's[/spoiler] route. That was a spin-off rather than another route! The main story was forgotten [spoiler](okay it was very briefly addressed post credits)[/spoiler] and we got a new setting with events that logically should have happened in the other routes too. 

What else... Music is nothing noteworthy, the whole thing is filled with fanservice tropes worse than another and performance issues with the engine during transitions are ever-present. [spoiler]Maika > Inori > Akane[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198199003009', 'num_games_owned': 591, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1553657027}
review:
Being the second Visual Novel in the LOVEKAMI series, this game puts us back in the world of goddesses. Instead of focusing on idols, in this visual novel we are assisting Akane, a naughty goddess  that we find one day at night through her rehabilitation since she's causing blackouts. With the help of Inori the earth goddess and our childhood friend Maika, our Main Character(MC) Sho Narumi assists her for the sake of both Akane and the apartment building as Akane is the protector goddess of it.

Like with Divinity Stage, the art and backgrounds are well made as always. Not to mention the character designs are unique(though Maika does resemble Sara from Divinity Stage a bit, but that might just be me). The music is good as well, but I prefer Divinity Stage thanks to multiple vocals with the songs. Regardless there is nothing wrong with the music.
Additionally, this visual novel only gives you one choice and like with Divinity Stage, its purpose is for the player to choose which of the girls' routes you will pursue. When you compare the routes, Akane's is the best of the three. Some scenes that are shown in all of the routes help her route the most. Inori's route suffers from being too short compared to the three and not having as much interactions with her and Sho when you compare the three. Maika's route was okay and I feel like her and Akane's route have good interactions between the characters, but Akane's route had a better story, conflict, and conclusion.


Overall, I recommend this visual novel as it looks good, it's decent, and a good novel to read through. It's currently on sale, so it's a good time to purchase it if you want to.

P.S. There is some fanservice in this game like in Divinity Stage, but nothing 18+

author: {'steamid': '76561198303993330', 'num_games_owned': 1425, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1545904759}
review:
LoveKami's second title, Useless Goddess, further improves on what made the first game a great read. In this novel, the themes around goddesses and idols are toned down in favor of a more slice-of-life approach. LoveKami Useless Goddess provides even more information and story surrounding the lore of Japanese goddesses and still keeps that cultural feel even with an entirely different plot. Not only are there a more diverse cast of girls to choose from, but the routes feel more diverse as well and all together comes as a solid improvement over the first game - which was already good in its own right.

Being a LoveKami game, once again we follow the story of the goddess, Akane, who wants to become an idol singer. However, she's deemed as unruly and neglects more rules than she follows, to the point where it threatens to ruin her life in the human world completely. The protagonist, Sho, stumbles across the goddess in the middle of the night during a blackout, and gets thrown into helping with her rehabilitation as a goddess. The shrine goddess Inori who was originally tasked with Akane's rehabilitation and Sho's best friend and landlady Maika all move in together to help Akane become a useful goddess.

LoveKami Useless Goddess is both an improvement and a step down from what Divinity Stage was. While there are more variety in where the routes end up going and the girls involved in them, any route that isn't Akane's feels really tacked on and rushed with no real dedication to where the story was going in the introduction. As with the previous LoveKami title, the relationship once you make your one and only choice is very rushed and the protagonist and girl of choice almost instantly fall for each other. This makes the routes only take a couple hours at most to complete, while condensing the romance down in favor of the rest of the story - at least in Akane's route. The other two routes are almost exclusively romance, setting the story aside for seemingly no reason other than not picking the girl the story is about. 

The story itself is really quite charming and cute, with Akane's route specifically clearly having more time and effort devoted to bringing the story to a conclusion by the end. Even if the other two characters aren't written as well and their routes feel a bit lackluster, there's still a lot of personality and uniqueness between them all and the game never feels like it copies tropes between characters. Mixed into the story once again, Japanese lore is very prevalent in LoveKami and its stories - discussing goddesses and shrine maidens belonging to traditional temples. The informational snips on the side are helpful to understand all the terminology for foreigners, making it a great game for anyone who loves Japanese culture.

LoveKami Useless Goddess, in my opinion, has a lower selling point than Divinity Stage. Both are listed for about $13, going on sale for about $5 often, but Useless Goddess lives up to that $5 sale tag much more than Divinity Stage does. Both are quality novels in their own right, but Useless Goddess has the downside of lacking in content and the feeling of endearment like Divinity Stage has. While Divinity Stage was about idols and packed with unique effects, distinctly unique characters and an overall feeling of life and vibrance no matter which route you choose, Useless Goddess takes the more subtle route to be a quiet little slice of life story where everything feels just the slightest bit more "normal" and dives less into the fantasy that Divinity Stage had, with only one route that really makes sense or matters. If you liked the first one, you may not like this one as much just because of the different turn it takes.

For those seeking 18+ content, LoveKami Useless Goddess really doesn't have any. There's a few slightly lewd scenes, but nothing worth a censorship bar. I personally don't think the 18+ content, should any ever exist, would fit very well with the type of story being told. It's a very romantic story with some light sexual flirtations that never go past that.

If you enjoyed the first LoveKami game and want to collect the series, Useless Goddess is a good game to pick up. For anyone who adores Japanese culture or visual novels in general, LoveKami Useless Goddess (and the other LoveKami titles) has everything you could ever want. It's still a well made visual novel with a lot of cheese and cliche, but doesn't hit home quite as hard as Divinity Stage did. I still recommend it for anyone who is interested, but wait for a sale and perhaps pick up Divinity Stage first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052286363', 'num_games_owned': 23, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1535107087}
review:
This game is living on the edge of despair, and though I sorta liked the music, it wasn't enough to push it over the top.  /ggwp

I was having problems whether to give this a good/bad review, because it is real close.  The main problem, is that the main character is a total dope; the girls do not make up for this, and the story is not particularly intelligent.  Thus, I cannot generally advise this game to wide audiences.  If you are a VN fan, and like these games however, it may be sufficient for such purposes.


Now, I would not call myself a "VN Expert", but the main character is horribly written:  He just talks to himself the whole time.  Plus, he is not very smart, self-aware, nor likeable.  Also, a bit of a pervy type.  "Shut up, Sho.  Let the girls talk, already.  We don't need you to tell us the sky is blue, that the sun rises in the East, 1+1=11; this isn't some stupid nature documentary.  It's so obvious..."

Akane's route is the only logic story choice.  Other ones are not well written, and seem to forget the whole "2 month time limit" premise of the story.  Inori route is a total ecchi-fest, with dopy Sho stupidness.  Maika's route is anti-climactic...  nothing to see here, moving on....

Alas, it would be nice if there was a complete/"Grand" route, perhaps Harem, that combined elements of all 3.  Then the game would be complete, Ret-2-Go.  Akane playthrough, again, is must.  Only logical conclusion.


I got around 8 hours from it, if auto-play natural read speed for new messages is observed.  ~4hour for first playthrough, ~2hour for additional routes.  Game was received as a free gift from Steam user.  Pay no mind to useless playtime number above; Offline Mode, 100% playthrough achievement FTW.

So it is how it is.  Perhaps, I should try other LoveKami titles in the series?  No matter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198221662964', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1533386406}
review:
Light-hearted, very cute and undemanding good entertainment for 6 to 8 hours.

Like "LoveKami: Divinity stage", "LoveKami: Useless Goddess" is visually stunning, not just because of the E-mote engine. It's well directed, has a cute story and endearing characters. The good voice actresses fit and help build the characters. Special kudos for Akane's voicing!

Compared to the first game, it seems there have been budget cuts on this one. There are only 10 (compared to 32) music tracks, and those also don't reach the quality level of "Divinity Stage".
Moreover, less care has been taken to E-mote-ing mouth animations while talking. The same is true for E-mote hiar movement.
Also, although a very minor issue, there's no config point that mutes sound if another window has the focus. It does mute when minimized though.

What may turn many players down is that it's basically a kinetic novel with only one option, where you can directly choose the route for one of the three girls to follow after a common route. I like kinetic novels, so it didn't matter for me.

85/100

review:
Dreadful. The word "useless" is an apt description for this title because that's really all it amounts to in the end.

Where the first game had a pleasant charm regardless of your [i]intentions[/i] for playing it, this game just falls flat. The story is incredibly short compared to the one in the first game and felt quite rushed at parts; my play hours are deceptive because I had to stop playing and walk away from this several times because of how mind-numbingly boring it got. 2 of the 3 routes available ended fairly abruptly and the last / "true" route, while better in that regard, took so long to get to that it wasn't even as satisfying as it probably should have been. The characters are vapid and the dialogue is written so lazily that the difference in the amount of effort that went into the first game and this one is almost palpable. 

With that being said, though, the game isn't [i]irredeemably[/i] bad. The character art is still beautiful and there's still lots of fanservice. Depending on your tolerance for garbage stories with cute anime waifus you might even enjoy this. I, however, did not. Anyone intending to play this for reasons other than simple titillation (i.e. meat-pounding material) will be sorely disappointed. Actually, even for that reason you'd still be wasting time and money on this considering there are far better, more enjoyable means of wasting hours of your life that not only satisfy your base urges but don't also make you want to smash your head against a wall. 

Skip.

Other than that I would also like to comment the fact that this is not the complete game. In Japan it is actually an 18+ title. While I don't think adding the 18+ scenes would make this much better, if at all, I do think it is pretty scummy to not release the full game. They could have just released the 18+ stuff as a patch. 

In conclution this is a boring incomplete VN that is poorly written.

review:
Should you get this game? Well, if you like cute love stories told in visual novel format, with a generous dollop of fanservice thrown in, then yes, you absolutely should. Otherwise, it might not be the game for you.

LoveKami -Useless Goddess- is not really a sequel to Pulltop/MoeNovel's other LoveKami game, though it takes place in the same universe. I haven't played that game myself, so I can't compare the two, but this game stands on its own quite well; you don't need to have played the first game in order to fully enjoy this one. The protagonist is a super-ordinary guy named Sho who, on his way back from the convenience store one night, runs into a girl passed out in the street. It turns out she's one of the goddesses that's come to Earth, although she's what's known as an "aragami" - a troublesome goddess, of sorts. Sho shares his food with her, and decides to bring her back home until they figure out what can be done for her. Wacky hijinks ensue almost immediately.

We're introduced to the three girls in the game: Akane, the aforementioned aragami whose power has been causing blackouts in the city; Inori, the town's guardian goddess whose responsibility it is to try and rehabilitate Akane; and Maika, the de facto landlady of the apartment complex where she and Sho live, and Sho's childhood friend. They all have their charms and they all fit at least a couple standard anime/VN tropes, which is par for the course for this type of game, I suppose. (And they all have absurdly large breasts, so hey, if that's your thing, you're in for a treat.)

The format of this game is a little different than most visual novels, in that there's very little interaction with the story. It is a "visual novel" in the purest sense - a text-based story told with slightly-animated pictures. Most games in the VN genre have you choosing dialogue options left and right, but not this game; you're pretty much just along for the ride. The game is divided into four distinct parts: there's the common route which establishes the back story and sets the scene for the rest of the game, and then there's individual routes for each of the three girls. The sole choice in this game is where the three individual routes branch off. (The easiest thing to do for completion is to save right at the choice screen, then re-load from that point to finish each of the individual routes.) I highly recommend that you do Maika's route last; the two goddesses can be done in either order, but there's some additional backstory in Maika's route that makes things seem... a little off if you do her route first. You can probably clear the game 100% in about 8 hours; 2 hours for the common route, and 2 hours for each of the individual routes.

Also, let's be clear about one thing: there is some mild fanservice in this game, but that's it. There's no R18 scenes or anything like that. Frankly, some of the most tittilating parts of the game aren't the visuals, but the descriptive text (and some of the accompanying voice lines). If you're expecting this game to be more porny than it is, you might be disappointed; however, if you're just expecting a bit of ecchi, I'd say it's perfect.

The visuals in this game are very nice; the girls are beautiful, and the backgrounds are rather well done (except for one scene where you're at a festival, and the text describes the venue as being packed with people, but the background is... completely empty of people). The sound design is great - the voice acting is excellent, and I found myself humming some of the background tunes to myself even while I wasn't playing. The options menu provides a good number of things to tweak, and there's a gallery for both images and audio once you've unlocked them through the story.

Overall, I definitely recommend this game. Each of the girls' individual routes present a really cute love story, with just enough raciness to liven things up (especially Maika's route, wow). If this sounds like your thing, you should absolutely pick up this game.

review:
So this is the second volume of the LoveKami series... at least on this side of the Pacific (I think there might be other games that are... more explicit in Japan with the name LoveKami). Unlike in the last one where you dealt with idols, this one starts around a goddess who is a bit more... carefree. As in, she doesn't like to follow the rules, which causes... problems. In this case, blackouts.

Her name is Akane Tsubaki, and she happens to stumble across the protagonist, Sho Narumi, who helps her and being kind-hearted agrees to let her follow him home... to the Tsubaki Apartments... who Akane is the house kami of, though she hadn't stumbled there after the Coming of the Goddesses. Soon following is Inori Kamiki, the goddess of Kannagi, the area of Tokyo the blackouts are occurring in. She is in charge of rehabbing Akane, as deities who do not control their powers, or Aragami, need to be rehabbed before they fade away... which would be bad for the places they are supposed to watch over.

Also there is Sho's childhood friend Maika Kunugi, who is the landlady as well.

Now there are three paths chosen during the one choice in the game (which actually takes place in the middle of the common path). Maika's is the traditional childhood friends become lovers (though not sleeping together lovers; no where in the game does it appear that happens).

Akane's... well, it's a nice path, since Akane starts to get rehabilitated because she is interested in becoming a local idol (which may or may not happen after the game ends). However, issues start to rise because she starts trying to not cause harm because of someone else... It does end very nicely, though. [spoiler] You learn that actually her blackouts (caused by her emotional instability) may actually have been holding off a worse blackout. But she makes it better.[/spoiler]

Inori's is also a great route. She is a bit earthy and innocent. And the ending is also great. There are also a few comedic notes about possible children (she's an earth deity, which also likely means fertility, so when they start having "relations", they may end up with a litter).

A fun read, filled with comedic notes. You should definitely try it. You may want to read the prior volume, Divinity Stage, first, though.

The town of Kannagi had suffered several blackouts lately. No one knows the cause of it - it is an absolute mystery.  Could it be a case of an Aragami Goddesss? My goodness, who knows?  It‚Äôs time to find out in LoveKami - Useless Goddess.

LoveKami ‚Äì Useless Goddess is an Anime / Visual Novel where you incarnate a character named Sho Nurami.  You will discover this story through his eyes.

This game is the sequel of LoveKami ‚Äì Divinity Stage and if you didn‚Äôt read the first novel, you‚Äòll need to know a few things. The Goddesses descended to earth a few years ago to live with humans and learn from each other. They have a special power called ‚ÄúJinriki,‚Äù and they use it to make people happy. To give you an example, some of the Goddesses become Idols and use this power to create special visuals when singing and dancing.  They are very kind to people and try to help them as much as possible.

In this story, Sho will come across an Aragami Goddess as he walks through the city late at night, on his way to is apartment.  Just before meeting the beautiful Akane, another blackout strikes the streets of Kannagi. Very quickly, Sho will find out that Akane struggles with her emotions and has difficulties controlling her ‚ÄúJinriki.‚Äù With the help of a female friend and another Goddess, they‚Äôre going to attempt to rehabilitate her to become the perfect Goddess. Otherwise she‚Äôll vanish from earth as a spirit, and no-one wants that to happen to the lovely Akane.

Most of the story will take place in Sho‚Äôs apartment block. There are a few other settings as scenery, but not as many as in the first novel. I really like the characters, especially Akane, who is the main one. The combination between the emotional goddess and her guardian (the other Goddess, who is worried about her becoming a spirit), is interesting. The different connections with Sho and the other three female persona are well done. Fairly early within the story, you‚Äôll have to choose which character you‚Äôre going to follow (path) and you‚Äôll be able to see three different endings. However, I would have enjoyed the visual novel even more if I had more choices. 

The visuals are very well done with occasional nudity and panties (giggle, giggle) but nothing extravagant (giggle, giggle). Facial expressions will change here and there as you progress through the dialogues. In regards to the soundtrack, it‚Äôs very nice and fits the game perfectly. I do think this sequel is shorter than its predecessor.

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

-	Nice visuals
-	Interesting characters
-	Easy to read
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	Shorter than its predecessor
-	Needs more options to choose from

LoveKami ‚Äì Useless Goddess is extremely easy to read with an interesting combination of characters.

7/10

But after playing all the routes, I felt that only Akane‚Äôs route was the ‚Äúreal‚Äù one and the only that made more sense. The story [i]is[/i] about her, after all. Inori‚Äôs route was very short and it wasn‚Äôt so interesting. Maika‚Äôs route was longer and it was okay. And that‚Äôs it. [h1]Full review on Sinical Network with accompanying screenshots and videos[/h1]
https://www.sinicalanimenetwork.com/post/2019/04/11/lovekami-useless-goddess-review

This is the third visual novel from PULLTOP and MoeNovel. [i]LoveKami -Useless Goddess-[/i] is a cute, funny, and heartwarming romantic comedy presented as a fairy tale that includes fanservice which is set in a modern Japanese time.  The story revolves around an Aragami who descended into Japanese society unintentially causing various degrees of trouble for humans. The main male protagonist Sho Narumi lives at Tsubaki Apartments in Kannagi town with his childhood friend and landlady Maika Kunugi, an Aragami Akane Tsubaki, as well as a local earth goddess and shrine maiden Inori Kamiki.

One night, while on his way home from a trip to a convenience store, Sho came across Akane appearing weak from starvation. Feeling sorry for her, Sho brought food for Akane to eat and allowed her to stay at the apartment.  He was shortly approached by Inori the shrine maiden, who explained that she was sent by her boss to be the guardian of Akane and oversee Akane Tsubaki's rehabilitation to remain as the household goddess of Tsubaki Apartments which has the ability to prevent Tsubaki Apartment's foundations and structures from rapid deterioration and eventual collapse.

Having played through and completed all routes in PULLTOP and MoeNovel's two visual novel releases on Steam [i]If My Heart Had Wings[/i] and [i]Lovekami -Divinity Stage-[/i], this visual novel is comparable to [i]Lovekami -Divinity Stage-[/i] in terms of animated sprites, plenty of attractive artwork in the game, free included wallpapers, and in the game cover, Steam achievements, profile backgrounds, badges, and emoticons which make it a good choice to showcase on your profile. The visual novel also has a nice opening movie and theme song to match the comedic and upbeat themes in the featured throughout the story.

There are a few negatives though.  This visual novel is much shorter than [i]LoveKami -Divinity Stage-[/i], with less text and dialogue to bring out each character in detail and only one choice to make in the entire game which automatically leads to one of three possible routes and endings (Less than 10 hours altogether to complete all 3 routes and endings). The soundtrack DLC for this visual novel has 1 soundtrack with vocals and 9 soundtracks which might reduce the appeal of the DLC and visual novel as it has considerably fewer songs with vocals compared to its earlier title [i]LoveKami -Divinity Stage-[/i]. As a short game with fan service, it might also disappoint readers who are looking for a more engaging romantic comedy featuring goddesses with supernatural powers.

Overall, [i]LoveKami -Useless Goddess-[/i] is a short romantic comedy with funny light-hearted moments, CGs with fanservice, and Steam achievements that can be unlocked and showcased on profile easily. At the same time, this visual novel is more disappointing than its earlier title of the LoveKami series by featuring fewer songs and BGM, and a shorter and more simplistic storyline. As such, this game is recommended only when it's at a good discount or bundle offer due to the short playing time and simple storyline.
